claim:
Consider the following background information: A 2-day-old infant male is brought to the emergency department with a 5-hour history of vomiting and irritability. He was born at home and had unreliable prenatal care because his parents have been experiencing housing instability. About a day after birth, he started to become lethargic and was feeding poorly. His parents thought that he might just be tired so they put him to bed; however, by the next morning he started to vomit and act extremely irritable. On presentation, he is found to have nuchal rigidity and bulging fontanelles. Based on this presentation, appropriate cultures are obtained and he is placed on empiric antibiotics. After all cultures grow out the same gram-positive bacteria, the patient is narrowed to penicillin G.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: Lipooligosaccharide rather than lipopolysaccharide is a characteristic of the most likely organism that is causing this patient"s symptoms.

supporting.text: Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative bacterium, is a common cause of neonatal meningitis and produces lipooligosaccharide (LOS) rather than lipopolysaccharide (LPS).

attacks.text: Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative bacterium, is a common cause of neonatal meningitis and produces lipooligosaccharide (LOS) rather than lipopolysaccharide (LPS).
The patient's cultures grew gram-positive bacteria, which contradicts the claim that Neisseria meningitidis (gram-negative) is the causative organism.
Gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) are more common causes of neonatal meningitis than gram-negative organisms in many settings.
The patient was born at home with unreliable prenatal care, increasing the risk of Group B Streptococcus infection due to lack of maternal screening and intrapartum prophylaxis.
While Neisseria meningitidis can cause meningitis, its LOS is structurally and functionally similar enough to LPS that the distinction may not be clinically significant in this case.

supporting.text: The clinical presentation of nuchal rigidity, bulging fontanelles, and irritability is consistent with bacterial meningitis, often caused by organisms like Neisseria meningitidis that produce lipooligosaccharide.

Group B Streptococcus is a plausible cause given the unreliable prenatal care, as it is often transmitted during childbirth from colonized mothers.

Lipooligosaccharide is a characteristic of Neisseria meningitidis, but the clinical presentation and demographics strongly favor Group B Streptococcus, which does not produce these molecules.
